title: 103_s1683
content: The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 may be cited as the Land Acquisition Act. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance protection of watersheds, outdoor recreation, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. The Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994 authorizes appropriations for acquiring land described in section 2 and allows for the transfer of funds to the Commission to carry out the Act. The Act may be cited as the "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994". The Palisades Interstate Park Commission manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. Sterling Forest, a biologically diverse area on the New Jersey border, covers approximately 17,500 acres and serves as a crucial watershed providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. It is also a significant outdoor recreational asset in the densely populated northeastern United States. Sterling Forest is a vital outdoor recreational area in the northeastern United States, supporting a variety of habitats and rare species. Protecting Sterling Forest would enhance the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and provide recreational opportunities. Stewardship costs are covered by New York and New Jersey, minimizing the need for federal funds. The Palisades Interstate Park Commission aims to acquire Sterling Forest for permanent protection due to its nationally significant watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities. This is a cost-effective investment compared to the costs of protecting drinking water in the region if the forest is developed. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect the watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources in the region. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and the management will be done by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. The definitions of terms like "Commission," "Reserve," and "Secretary" are provided in the Act. The Sterling Forest Reserve is established to protect the region's watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and management will be handled by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. The Sterling Forest Reserve is established in New York to protect the region's resources. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres of lands. Federal funds are authorized for land acquisition, and management will be handled by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. The Commission must adhere to specific terms and conditions when managing lands within the Sterling Forest Reserve. This includes conveying fee title to the United States if management is not consistent with the Act, obtaining consent from landowners before acquiring lands with Federal funds, prioritizing the acquisition of designated easement lands, and taking action within 30 days of acquiring specified lands. The Commission must convey conservation easements on acquired lands within the Reserve to the United States, ensuring protection of wilderness character and limiting development to preserve the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. The Commission must convey conservation easements on acquired lands within the Reserve to the United States to protect wilderness character and limit development in line with the Appalachian National Scenic Trail management plan. Funds for the Commission must be matched by non-Federal sources. The Commission will manage lands in the Reserve according to its authorities and the Act's purposes. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years for approval by the Secretary. Appropriations are authorized for the Act's implementation, with a limit of $17,500,000 for land acquisition within the Reserve.
